rationale: This hypothesis is the most directly testable with modest engineering: the proposed proxies can be computed from quantities already available during training (gradients, norms, step-to-step changes) without implementing new second-order machinery. It scales well in an academic lab because it can be validated across small-to-mid GANs/datasets with many seeds and controlled perturbations, yielding statistically solid results. If the proxy robustly predicts blow-ups earlier and better than loss-only baselines, it is a clear, publishable contribution as a diagnostic/measurement tool and can serve as a foundation for subsequent adaptive-control methods.

feasibility_scores.brief_reason: Requires designing and tuning an ADOE controller plus defining stable rotation metrics; feasibility depends on the proxy quality and careful ablations to avoid confounding with generic regularization.

Low implementation overhead (uses existing training signals), can be evaluated with straightforward correlation/forecasting protocols across seeds, and is compute-feasible while still offering a novel, reusable diagnostic.
Wall-clock claims are brittle (hardware, I/O, mixed precision, implementation details) and require extensive, tightly controlled benchmarking to be credible at top venues.
Testable but expensive: needs large hyperparameter grids with multiple seeds and careful fairness controls; results can be noisy and may hinge on architecture/loss choices.
